race.name: GRINDURO CANADA
race.tagline: Race inside a 450-million-year-old meteorite crater where the party is as legendary as the singletrack

vitals.format: 4 timed enduro stages within gravel course

logistics.explanation: Remote Quebec location requires significant planning, but Caitlin Bernstein notes the opportunity to visit near Devinci's HQ and connect with Canadian friends. Quebec City airport is 60+ miles away, Montreal is 4 hours, and the metric course markings confused some US riders - Bernstein admits 'my brain was having a hard time with the metric system while also trying to ride hard.'

length.explanation: At 67 miles, the enduro format with timed segments means you're racing only 7-12 minute intervals within the longer loop. As Bernstein explains, this 'takes the stress of I can't even stop for water/snacks or I might get dropped out of the equation' since you can ride at party pace between the four competitive segments. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Caitlin Bernstein puts it: "The segments/course were mapped in kilometers, with climbs in meters. This had me all sorts of confused - the first segment was longer and more climbing than I thought and the 2nd segment was much sho..."

technicality.explanation: Course demands serious bike handling skills through sand, loose gravel, grass, and singletrack descents. Matt Surch describes it as 'next-level sandy' while one rider reported 'the sand along the middle part of the route was brutal, I was slipping all over the place.' Bernstein ran 40mm Schwalbe G-One Bite tires specifically for the technical terrain mix. More technical than most — comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Gravel Union reviewer puts it: "The ride itself was one of the toughest 100km I have ever ridden … delivering somewhere just north of 2000m of climbing and predominantly on gravel, often with a fair dose of sand, we worked for our b..."

elevation.explanation: The 5,900-foot climbing total is shaped by the ancient meteorite impact that created Charlevoix's topography. Bernstein notes the course segments had more climbing than expected when converted from metric, with the terrain formed 350 million years ago when 'a meteorite struck the area' - creating the rolling, relentless landscape riders face today. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds. As Gravel Union reviewer puts it: "Stage 2: OUCH! A tarmac climb … we hit gradients that had me wondering how they got the tarmac to stick to the hill! Any effort as the stage started to 'race' soon subsided to just surviving."

climate.explanation: August conditions in Charlevoix allow for post-race activities like river dips, as Bernstein enjoyed 'cold beers, a river dip and delicious local food' after racing. The comfortable temperatures support the festival atmosphere, though the region's humid continental climate brings rain risk that can turn the technical terrain slick. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL. As Gravel Union reviewer puts it: "The ride itself was one of the toughest 100km I have ever ridden … delivering somewhere just north of 2000m of climbing and predominantly on gravel, often with a fair dose of sand, we worked for our b..."

altitude.explanation: Racing near sea level in the St. Lawrence lowlands means zero altitude concerns. The meteorite crater setting sits in Quebec's lowlands without elevation-related breathing challenges - riders can focus entirely on the technical terrain and sandy sections without acclimatization factors. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Racing inside a 450-million-year-old meteorite crater delivers unique terrain found nowhere else in gravel racing. As Bernstein observed, 'the topography of the region was created by a meteorite that struck the area 350 million years ago - not sure if it gets much more unique than that?!' The cosmic impact created the landscape that challenges modern cyclists.

prestige.explanation: Part of the pioneering Grinduro series but remains the smaller, more intimate version. Bernstein found it 'felt really similar to the California Grinduro that I've come to love, just a much smaller version and a bit more French.' The Canada edition draws serious riders but lacks the iconic status of the original California event.

race_quality.explanation: Professional organization with clear course markings and the refined Grinduro festival model. Bernstein praises how 'organizers and sponsors put a lot of effort into setting up and sourcing local vendors' for the camping, food, expo, music, and photo booth elements that define the Grinduro experience when executed properly.

experience.explanation: Delivers Grinduro's signature 'perfect party to race ratio' with camping, food, music, and river access. Bernstein captures the essence: 'These events are set up with fun in mind - camping, food, beer, expo, music, the volunteers, the photo booth, the river.' The format values having fun at the party as much as racing fast on the course.

community.explanation: Attracts riders who value experience over pure competition, creating the festival atmosphere Grinduro is known for. The event philosophy prioritizes inclusivity - 'having a good time at the party is just as important as going fast in the race' - while the French-Canadian setting adds unique cultural character to the typical Grinduro community vibe. As Overall vibe puts it: "The vibes. These events are set up with fun in mind- camping, food, beer, expo, music, the volunteers, the photo booth, the river… All of these things play into the good vibes at Grinduro and it's cle..."

field_depth.explanation: Regional competitive field without major pro presence, drawing enthusiasts like Bernstein who appreciate the opportunity to race while visiting the Devinci area and connecting with Canadian cycling friends. The remote Quebec location and smaller scale limit elite participation compared to the flagship California Grinduro. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Matt Surch puts it: "Since GRINDURO sort of came up unexpectedly, I left my setup as I'd been riding it in 2021, biased toward fast gravel."

value.explanation: Entry fee ($200-300 CAD) includes substantial meals - Saturday breakfast, lunch, and three-course dinner, plus Sunday breakfast. Add festival access, camping available for $25, and you're getting value for a weekend experience.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $200-300. Remote Quebec location drives up total costs through required flights, rental cars, and limited accommodation near Saint-Urbain. International travelers face border crossing logistics, and the specialized tire setup - Bernstein used 40mm tubeless Schwalbe G-One Bite at 30 psi front/32 rear - shows equipment considerations for the sandy, technical terrain. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

final_verdict.one_liner: A mountain bike race disguised as gravel, where meteorite-shaped terrain separates the prepared from the delusional.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you panic on technical singletrack or think 25mm tires are acceptable, stay home. This demands MTB skills, fat rubber, and comfort with getting your ego adjusted by Quebec sand pits. The festival vibes and excellent food soften the blow, but won't save you from walking the steep, loose climbs that eat narrow tires alive.
final_verdict.alternatives: Mid South offers similar technical challenge with better race organization and guaranteed scheduling. Grinduro California delivers the same format with more predictable conditions and without the language barrier that might complicate logistics in rural Quebec.

course_description.character: Grinduro Canada drops you inside a 450-million-year-old meteorite crater where Mother Nature has been plotting your demise since the Ordovician period. Four timed segments demand everything from singletrack handling to sand survival, connected by 'neutral' sections that aren't neutral at all. This isn't gravel racing—it's enduro with a gravel entry fee.

suffering_zones.label: First Stage Reality Check
suffering_zones.desc: The opening timed segment hits immediately and reminds you this isn't your typical gravel sufferfest. Technical singletrack with roots and rocks separates the mountain bikers from the road converts real fast.

suffering_zones.label: The Crater Climb
suffering_zones.desc: Steep, loose pitches where smaller tires spin helplessly and riders dismount in waves. The meteorite impact created these gradients specifically to humble your gear choices.

suffering_zones.label: Soul-Sucking Sand
suffering_zones.desc: Deep sand sections that swallow momentum and spit out confidence. Your legs burn, your bike wallows, and you question every life decision that led here.

suffering_zones.label: Eastern Ruggedness
suffering_zones.desc: The wild side of the crater reveals its true character through technical descents and relentless elevation changes. Canyon views are gorgeous until you realize you have to climb back out.

course_description.signature_challenge: The course pretends to be gravel but demands full mountain bike skills across four timed segments that expose every weakness in your technical repertoire. Ancient meteorite impacts created terrain that laughs at road bike geometry and narrow tires—show up on the wrong equipment and the crater will humble you publicly.

videos.title: Grinduro Canada 2021 Hosted by EVIL
videos.description:
400 million years ago, a meteorite hit the Canadian Shield and its Laurentian massif here in Charlevoix. It is this phenomenal shock that created the breathtaking landscapes and rugged terrain that make the Charlevoix region famous, and a place that delights (or tortures) cyclists.

It is thus no surprise that we chose Saint-Urbain-de-Charlevoix, to host Grinduro Canada. But what exactly is a Grinduro? It’s a combo of a gravel grinder road race and an enduro: one long loop on all kinds of terrain, where finishing times aren’t based on overall loop time, but four timed segments.
